title: coronavirus-borders-recycling-centres-close-due-virus
story: TWO recycling centres in the Borders have closed due to a member of staff testing positive for coronavirus.The community recycling centres at Eshiels and Hawick will close for the remainder of today .A Tweet shared by Scottish Borders Council today at .pm reads: "Our community recycling centres at Hawick and Eshiels will be closed for the remainder of today after a member of staff tested positive for COVID-."UPDATE: The two recycling centres are open as normal today .

title: not-take-rugby-match-borders
story: Another feast of live rugby is taking place in the region and beyond this weekend including a Premiership Borders derby between Selkirk and Jed-Forest at Philiphaugh. Elsewhere Hawick travel to league leaders Currie.In National League Division One Gala will take the long trip to face Highland, Melrose host Ayr, Kelso are in the capital to meet Watsonians and Biggar host Boroughmuir at Hartree Mill.In National League Division Two Peebles welcome Glasgow Accies.In National League Division Three Berwick host Strathmore.In National East League One Duns host Linlithgow.In National East League Two Hawick Linden have a home game against Livingston.In the Tennentrsquos East Reserve League One Hawick Force have an away game at Currie A whilst Selkirk A host Jed-Forest A.In the Tennentrsquos East Reserve League Two Gala A are away to Linlithgow A, Melrose Storm host Watsonians A and Peebles Reds take on Kelso Sharks at the Gytes.In the Semi-Junior Border League Jed Thistle host Tynedale Colts, Selkirk Youth are at home to Carlisle Colts, Kelso Harlequins take on Hawick Youth at Poynder Park, Melrose Wasps host a Borders derby against Gala Wanderers at the Greenyards and Peebles Colts welcome Duns Colts.On Sunday Scotland take on Australia in the second game of the Autumn Series at BT Murrayfield. Kick off .pm

title: borders-buses-cancels-service-due-coronavirus
story: A BORDERS Buses services will not run today due to an ongoing outbreak of coronavirus.The X service ndash which operates between Galashiels and Hawick ndash will not run today following initial cancellations on Wednesday .A Borders Buses spokesperson said: "We had expected to cancel more journeys on more routes tomorrow, however our team ndash who are going above and beyond ndash are working round the clock to keep our buses moving."Services which are cancelled today include:X from Hawick ndash  Hawick to Galashiels X from Galashiels ndash  Galashiels to Hawick   Galashiels to Hawick The earlier  Hawick to Galashiels  and  Hawick to Galashiels  services, as well as the  Galashiels to Hawick  services were also cancelled.The spokesperson added: "We would like to highlight many of our drivers are giving up their much needed day off to ensure our customers can travel."This is a huge testament to our amazing team, and we ask you ndash where relevant ndash to recognise their efforts."As you can imagine the outbreak is once again causing anxiety, so we are reinforcing the hands, face and space message to our team and customers."We shall do our upmost to keep our customers updated on any further changes."

title: tesco-gala-helps-raise-funds-three-worthwhile-charities
story: SHOPPERS in Galashiels have been thanked for contributing towards the poundmillion raised for three le-saving charities as part of Tescorsquos lsquoHelping you to live healthierrsquo initiative.Tesco customers reached the landmark total for Cancer Research UK, the British Heart Foundation and Diabetes UK from - September by rounding up their shop in store to the nearest pound.The funds raised will now help the three charities continue their vital work to save and improve lives.In addition to the poundmillion donated, the campaign raised awareness in Galashiels about the importance of people making sustainable lestyle changes that can help lower their risk of cancer, heart and circulatory diseases, and type  diabetes.This was done with the help of trusted health information and advice, which was shared to empower Tesco customers to take small steps to help improve their health.Oonagh Turnbull, Head of Health Campaigns at Tesco, thankedshoppers in Galashiels for their generosity, which will make a signicant dference to many peoplersquos lives.She added: ldquoIt has been inspiring to see our customers really engage with the work we are doing together, and we hope that we have played a part in raising awareness for these conditions, as well as le-saving funds.The campaign was part of the Health Charity Partnership between Tesco, Cancer Research UK, the British Heart Foundation and Diabetes UK, which aims to inspire and support Tesco colleagues, customers and their families to make healthier food choices and live healthier lives.On behalf of the charity partners , Claire Sadler, Executive Director of Marketing, Fundraising and Engagement at the British Heart Foundation, said: ldquoWe have been amazed by the incredible generosity of Tesco customers and colleagues and would like to thank everyone who donated during September.ldquoYour donations will help to empower millions of people to make healthier choices that lower their risk of heart and circulatory diseases, cancer, and diabetes. It will also help our charities provide vital support to millions of people at a time itrsquos never been more needed, and it will fund research with the potential to save lives.

title: peeblesshire-woman-ran-marathon-memory-beautiful-mum
story: A BORDERS woman completed the London Marathon in memory of her "beautul mum" who passed away following a battle with cancer.Fiona Kennedy, from Peebles, ran her first marathon in  to mark her mother completing  years of treatment for soft tissue cancer and to raise money for Sarcoma UK ndash the charity which had supported her mum throughout her treatment.After completing the Edinburgh race in May  and raising pound,, Fionas mum passed away at the age of  in September ."Mumrsquos ethos meant that she took the years of surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and drug trials in her stride," said Fiona. "She continued to travel, play an active part in her grandchildrenrsquos lives and was a much-loved we, mum, sister, and aunt.":Feast of live rugby available for fans in the Borders this weekendAlthough shed sworn to never run again, Fiona, her aunt, uncle and cousins agreed to run a marathon in her mums memory.The family promptly signed up to run the London Marathon  for Sarcoma UK.However, the coronavirus pandemic meant last years marathon was postponed.But despite lockdown, Fiona continued to train for when the marathon was rearranged for October this year.:Man threatened to kill his partner during a bust-up in the Borders"I swore I would never run again after Edinburgh and I crossed the line in London two years later having raised a further pound, for Sarcoma UK," said Fiona."I have been out running in my finishers t-shirt twice since completing London, and I have felt a real sense of accomplishment pounding the pavements in that prestigious t-shirt."Crossing the finish line was a huge sense of relief."My cousin Lucy and I crossed it together hand in hand and promptly burst into tears."The sense of achievement was felt immediately, not least because the staff, marshals and volunteers were amazing in their support and care."The congratulations came from runners, supports and strangers..remove"Mum wasnrsquot at the finish line in London but Irsquom sure she would have been amazed and proud in equal measures.":Photo Gallery: Some of the best Halloween costumes from across the BordersFiona is now looking forward to ing to sports she enjoys, but can also see herself joining in park runs.She said: "I am looking forward to ing to other forms of exercise that I love, but I do see myself factoring in the odd Parkrun to tick my legs over."In terms of fundraising ndash I will have a lelong affiliation with Sarcoma UK."Mum wanted to do more in terms of contributing to research, raising awareness and rising funds, and this is a duty I have inherited."I will continue to look for ways to support the charity I have such fondness for."

title: christine-grahame-turn-galashiels-shop-new-office
story: AN MSP will turn a shop on Galashiels High Street into her constituency office after plans were approved by the council.Christine Grahame, an SNP representative for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale, will take over the space occupied by The Enchanted Florist.Despite stating that a retail unit would have been ldquopreferred, Scottish Borders Council officers have given the green light to change the use of the property to an office.:Borders Buses: Service cancellations continue following coronavirus outbreakOn the decision, Ms Grahame said: ldquoI am pleased that I can now move forward and re-open a constituency office in Galashiels, where I have been for the last  years ndash it is central to the constituency with good public transport links which is essential.ldquoWith some necessary adaptations due to COVID and for security purposes I hope it will be fully ing before the end of the year.ldquoIn the meantime my Tesco surgeries in Galashiels and Peebles will commence this month and you can still, as always, contact me and my staff by phone or email or by writing to me at parliament ndash details are on my website.

title: peebles-choir-appoints-new-musical-director
story: A BORDERS choir has welcomed its new musical director.Peebles-based choir InChorus said it is ldquodelighted to welcome Au Arias to the choir.Au, who is originally from Argentina, has worked with choirs and orchestras in five countries and worked in Turkey for three years as opera director at the Samsun State Opera and Ballet before moving to Scotland with his we last year.Au said: ldquoI have always been interested in big choirs and am very happy to be given the opportunity to work with InChorus in this lovely Borders town.ldquoDespite the many months of being unable to sing together I am amazed at their ability and determination to sound good.The choir spent a number of months without a musical director as the coronavirus pandemic limited opportunities to meet with candidates.Choir manager Cath Shepheard said: ldquoInChorus had been without an MD for some months because the pandemic restrictions prevented our large choir meeting potential candidates in person.ldquoWe thank Au for his patience in waiting for us, and are very pleased that he is with us now.InChorus willto singing for audiences this winter with a performance at this yearrsquos Peebles Christmas Lights Switch On on Sunday, November .They will then sing at Pentland Plants in Edinburgh on December  and at Jupiter Artland Christmas Fair on Sunday, December .Au added: ldquoI have encouraged the choir to take part in some Christmas events to build our performance confidence.ldquoAfter that we will be working on something dferent.ldquoInChorus prides itself in being open to new musical experiences and I intend to give them that.To find out more about InChorus, including how to join the choir, contact Cath at: manager@inchoruschoir, through the website on www.inchoruschoir, on Facebook or Twitter.

title: enrolment-week-parents-apply-borders-school-places
story: PARENTS are invited to register their children for a school place for August  during enrolment week.From November -, parents of any child who is five years old before February ,  can fill in an online application.They will need to have electronic copies of their childrsquos birth certicate and proof of address available to upload along with their application.They should then make contact with their local primary school to confirm the application has been made.Parents of a child whose fth birthday falls between August ,  and February ,  have the right to defer their childrsquos entry to primary school.Applications for deferred entry should be discussed with the head teacher or early learning and childcare setting manager.Any parent intending to make a placement request for their child at a school other than their local catchment school should enrol with their local school in the normal way using the online form.They should also contact their preferred school and complete the online placement request form, available online at: www.scotborders.gov.uk schoolenrolment from November .Children who are moving from primary to secondary school in August  will receive details of the local catchment school from their current primary school.Early learning and childcareenrolment week for three and four year olds will take place from January - .Councillor Carol Hamilton, executive member for children and young people, said: ldquoParents of any child due to start Primary  are asked to complete the online form that will be available during enrolment week.ldquoThe online process is one that was introduced as part of our response to the pandemic and we hope parents continue to find helpful and straightforward.More information about the enrolment process is available at: www.scotborders.gov.uk schoolenrolment or on   or at: hqoperations@scotborders.gov.uk

title: scott-brash-statue-plans-monument-add-new-dimension
story: THE Olympic legacy of Scott Brash, which was honoured with the erection of a statue, could soon be illuminated with a golden glow.The showjumper landed back in Peebles to unveil the lesize sculpture in recognition of his gold medal back in .The tribute to one of the regionrsquos greatest ever sportsmen was warmly welcomed by the community, and is a spectacular vision on entry to the town from Edinburgh Road.The project was the brainwave of voluntary group Bonnie Peebles, which commissioned the sculpture, which artist Kevin Paxon designed and created from recycled horseshoes.Now, community leaders would like to highlight his golden glory further and hope to work with Bonnie Peebles to clear the final hurdle in this project.During a meeting of Peebles Community Council, members discussed installing lighting at the monument. It was suggested that solar-powered lights would be the most cost-effective option.Tweeddale East councillor Robin Tatler said an application to fund the lighting could be submitted to the Peebles Parking Fees Fund.Chairman Les Turnbull said: ldquoThe Scott Brash monument is a wonderfully impressive artwork at the gateway to the town.ldquoTo have it lit would add another dimension for us all to enjoy, particularly as the nights draw in.

title: sbc-place-making-priority-list-questioned-meeting
story: SCOTTISH Borders Councilrisks annoying communities not on a list of suggested lsquopriorityrsquo areas for initial support, a meeting has been told.lsquoPlace-makingrsquo ndash an initiative which aims to ldquotransform the working relationship between the council and communities ndash was discussed at a meeting of the Tweeddale Area Partnership on Tuesday .At the virtual gathering, SBC programme officer James Lamb said that place-making is ldquoall about involving local people in the place that they live and identying their needs and priorities, working out an action plan that addresses those and starting to implement projects.Innerleithen and Walkerburn are the two lsquoTweeddalersquo areas selected on a potential shortlist for ldquoinitial place-making activity created by council officers.On the suggested priority areas, Tweeddale East councillor Stuart Bell, of the SNP, said the council should ldquofocus on those communities that have initiative and want to take initiative.He added: ldquoIn terms of assessing communities, I think we should bin the list thatrsquos in front of us becauseI was in Tweeddale West - Eddleston, Carlops, West Linton, Brouhgton or Skirling - I would be less than pleased that I didnrsquot see my community appearing on that list andI was in Tweeddale East - in Cardrona or Clovenfords - Irsquod also be p***** off.Earlier in the meeting, Tweeddale West councillor Heather Anderson, also of the SNP, said that place-making should ldquostart from the bottom up rather than from a list.ldquoThis is about communities leading on how we draft a locality plan for the Borders, so instead of us drafting a locality plan and consulting communities wersquore trying to say, lsquoYou write the plan and wersquoll assimilate up the way.rsquoldquoThis [list] is tending towards, lsquoWhere are the needs and deficiencies rsquo instead of, lsquoWhere are the communities that are bursting with ideas and enthusiasm, ready to get going to make a change rsquo.removeldquoThey will teach the other communities the benefit of the engagement. Itrsquos coming from them and wersquore picking up on their energy, rather than assessing them to see whether or not they fit the criteria for us to work with them.Mr Lamb said the list was ldquojust a suggestion but said that Ms Andersonrsquos proposal could be a ldquogreat approach.On Ms Andersonrsquos suggestion, Tweeddale East councillor Shona Haslam, of the Conservatives, said: ldquoMy only concern is that wersquoll end up prioritising communities already doing a lot and attracting a lot of funding. While I understand and support the concept of demonstrating best practice and allowing that to trickle through, perhaps we should look at a model of linking up communities, so a community that isnrsquot doing very well with one that is doing well in a mentoring programme.ldquoI worry slightly that itrsquoll be Newcastleton that gets everything because Newcastleton are extremely good at having lots of community projects and attracting a lot of community funding.ldquoI would be slightly anxious going down that route full throttle.The council leader added: ldquoI donrsquot want anyone to be left behind or just the usual suspects to be getting the support.Ms Anderson, who supported Mrs Haslamrsquos comments, said: ldquoWe can get somewhere with thiswe shake it about a bit.

title: sbc-first-local-authority-scotland-use-road-surface
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council is the first local authority in Scotland to use a road surface which is expected to improve durability, a meeting has heard.The surface course specication, TS, is also skid resistant, according to council officer Donald Scott.Mr Scott told a meeting of the Tweeddale Area Partnership on Tuesdaythat TS had previously only been used on trunk roads, with the council the first in the country to try it on a rural network.He also gave an update on the Pothole Pro, trialled by the local authority earlier this year.ldquoWe hope it will be here early next year, said Mr Scott. ldquoWersquore reviewing the best way to deliver that.The JCB machine claims to fix potholes four times quicker than normal ndash and at half the cost.Member of the public Neil McCarroll asked Mr Scott about the standard of repairs, adding that the ldquosame potholes need repairing every year.Mr Scott explained that potholes are split into dferent categories which need to be temporarily dealt with within a certain period of time.ldquoItrsquos very dficult to carry out permanent repairs on seven and -day defects becausewe started to carry out permanent repairs on those we wouldnrsquot get round the network, he said.Temporary repairs are usually carried out by the councilrsquos in-house contractor, but the local authority brought in external contractors in the last financial year ldquobecause of the number of potholes on the network, according to Mr Scott.

title: borders-records-80-coronavirus-cases-24-hours
story: THE Borders has recorded  new cases of coronavirusin the last day, latest figures show.According to Scottish Government data published at pm today , the Borders has now seen , cases of the virus since the start of the pandemic.:Borders Buses: Service cancellations continue following coronavirus outbreakThere remain  people in the hospital in the Borders with confirmed cases of the virus.Scotland has now recorded , cases of the virus since March last year, according to the latest data.

title: coronavirus-map-highlights-borders-cases
story: AN INTERACTIVE Borders map shows the locations of new cases of coronavirusin the region.The Borders is split into  neighbourhoods on the Public Health Scotland tool.The map displays data from the period October -November .According to the map, Burnfoot recorded the highest seven-day rate per , of ,. during that period.Coldstream and Area recorded a case rate of ., Hawick Central had a rate of ., Hawick West End had a rate of ., Berwickshire East reported a rate of ., Hawick North recorded a rate of ., Kelso North had a rate of ., Jedburgh recorded a rate of ., Cheviot East reported a case rate of ., Galashiels South had a rate of ., Kelso South recorded a rate of ., and Denholm and Hermitage had a case rate of ..Sixteen areas recorded cases rates between - per ,.These areas included: Langlee , Tweeddale West Area , Selkirk , St Boswells and Newtown and Area , Duns , Chirnside and Area , Berwickshire Central , Tweeddale East Area , Eyemouth , Earlston Stow and Clovenfords Area , Cheviot West , Galashiels West , Ettrick Yarrow and Lilliesleaf Area , Peebles South , Peebles North , and Melrose and Tweedbank Area .Lauder and Area recorded a seven-day case rate between - per , of the populationand Galashiels North recorded a case rate of ..To find your area, click hereand then select lsquocases by neighbourhoodrsquo.You might also be interested in:Borders woman appears at court on consecutive days for breaching bailconditionsSeveral organised fireworksdisplays in Borders this weekendBorders Buses: Service cancellationscontinue following coronavirus outbreak

title: linda-mccall-borders-council-admits-liability-civil-case
story: SCOTTISH Borders Councilhas reportedly admitted liability after a teacher was convicted of assaulting children with learning dficulties.Linda McCall was found guilty earlier this year of assaulting five pupils between August  and October  while employed by the local authority, as well as one count of threatening or abusive behaviour.McCall had previously been cleared of any wrongdoing after an internal investigation was carried out by the council following complaints from parents.:Borders woman appears at court on consecutive days for breaching bail conditionsOn reports that SBC has now admitted liability in the civil case launched by the parents, Christine Grahame ndash MSP for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale constituency ndash has accused the council of ldquoan abhorrent breach of trust.ldquoThe parents have now been vindicated in both the criminal court and civil court, however this I know is cold comfort, the SNP representative said. ldquoAt the centre of all this we have young children, often non verbal and unable to clearly communicate, who have been traumatised by the abuse they endured, abuse which they were unable to understand or communicate to anyone.ldquoIt is an abhorrent breach of trust by those we trust to care for the most vulnerable in society and SBC must face up to its role in this.Ms Grahame added that it has been ldquothree and a half years of an uphill slog to try and get a semblance of justice for these families.:Borders Buses: Service cancellations continue following coronavirus outbreakAn independent inquiry into how the council dealt with complaints made about McCall is currently ongoing.A Scottish Borders Council spokesperson said: ldquoThis remains an ongoing legal matter, which is being undertaken on behalf of Scottish Borders Council by external solicitors, and it has not yet been finalised. We have no further comment to make at this stage..removeldquoAn independent inquiry led by Andrew Webster QC, which is considering the councilrsquos handling of concerns raised about the former employee, is still ongoing. As soon as this work is completed we will look to share its outcomes.

title: a7-skippers-wall-lane-closures-impact-motorists-2-weeks
story: DAYTIME lane closures will impact a major road for two weeks, Borders motorists are being warned.Maintenance and upgrade works are planned at the A Skippers Wall - at the north end of Skippers Bridge, which carries the A over the River Esk south of Langholm.Works will begin on the morning of Monday, November , and will end in the afternoon on Friday, December .The lane closure will be between am and pm on each weekday, according to a BEAR Scotland spokesperson.:Borders Buses: Service cancellations continue following coronavirus outbreakChris Tracey, BEAR Scotlandrsquos south east network manager, said: ldquoThis lane closure is essential to allow us to maintain and upgrade the A Skippers Wall.ldquoWe have scheduled the works during daylight hours to enhance the safety of road users and BEAR personnel.ldquoWe have planned the works to minimise disruption, howeveryou do need to use this route during this period our advice is to plan ahead and allow extra time for your journey.During the works, BEAR Scotland will ldquorepoint defective areas of the masonry wall, cut the vegetation above the wall and install timber fencing for the safety of personnel on future maintenance activities.

title: free-bus-travel-22s-january-says-borders-msp
story: UNDER s will be able to ride the bus for free from January, according to a Borders MSP.Christine Grahame, Holyrood representative for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale, said the announcement will help to meet a key manesto pledge by the SNP in the May elections.Those under the age of  in the Borders will benefit from free bus travel from January .On the announcement, Ms Grahame, of the SNP, said: ldquoThe SNP Scottish Government is once again making an investment in our young peoplersquos future. By making bus travel free for under s in the Borders and across Scotland, opportunities for young people to work, travel and study are being opened up for them.ldquoTravelling by bus is one of the most environmentally friendly ways to get across the country and research shows that young people recognise the vital role public transport will play in hitting our climate change targets.ldquoThis move will not only be vital in our journey to net zero, but will also take pressure off young people and their familiesrsquo finances.

title: scotland-v-australia-channel-scotland-rugby-game
story: Scotlandwill play Australia in their second match of the rugby autumn series this weekend at Murrayfield.Last week the team played against Tonga in front of a home crowd, winning - in an impressive match.Now turning their attention to Australia, the odds look slightly tipped in Scotlands favour, having won the last two matches against the team.With the fansbehind them once again, they will look to repeat last Saturdays triumphant performance as they go against the Aussies for the first time since .As rugby enthusiasts once again fill up the Edinburgh stadium, heres how you can watch at home...Kick-off time for Scotland v Australia match this weekend The Scotland v Australia match will take place at Murrayfield on Sunday November  at .pm.It is the teams second match in the autumn series, which will take place throughout November.What channel isScotland v Australiaand how to watch live Amazon Prime hasthe broadcast rights for the autumn international series in the UK.You will need a membership to tune in, butyou dont already have one you can sign up to a -day free trial.If you dont want to continue your trial after the -days however, you will need to remember to cancel your subscription.When is Scotlands next match in autumn series Here is Scotlands schedule for the autumn series:Scotland v Australia: Sunday November  at .pmScotland v South Africa: Saturday November  at pmScotland v Japan: Saturday November  at pmWhats the Scotland team line-up Stuart HoggDarcy Graham, Chris Harris, Sam Johnson, Duhan van der Merwe Finn Russell, Ali Price Pierre Schoeman, George Turner, Zander Fagerson, Sam Skinner, Grant Gilchrist, Jamie Ritchie, Hamish Watson, Matt Fagerson.Replacements:Ewan Ashman, Jamie Bhatti, Oli Kebble, Jamie Hodgson, Josh Bayliss, George Horne, Adam Hastings, Kyle Steyn.

title: german-covid-infection-rate-reaches-new-high-vaccinations-slow
story: Germanyrsquos coronavirus infection rate has climbed to its highest recorded level yet as what officials have termed a ldquopandemic of the unvaccinated gathers pace.The national disease control centre, the Robert Koch Institute, said the country has seen . new cases per , residents over the past seven days. That was above the previous record of . from December  last year.While it is still a lower rate than in several other European countries, the figure has set alarm bells ringing.The seven-day infection rate has long ceased to be the only yardstick for Covid- policy in Germany, but officials say hospitals are filling up in badly affected areas.The disease control centre said on Monday that , new cases were reported over the past  hours ndash down from a record , on Friday, but figures are typically lower after the weekend.Germany has struggled to find ways to pep up its slowing vaccination campaign. At least % of the population of  million is fully vaccinated, according to official figures, which authorities say is not enough.vw,vw,px, px"A woman walks past an abandoned coronavirus test centre in Frankfurt Unlike some other European countries, it has balked at making vaccinations mandatory for any professional group.As at many times during the pandemic, Germany has a patchwork of regional rules. Most places restrict access to many indoor facilities and events to people who have been vaccinated, have recovered or been tested mdash with the latter now being excluded in some areas. Enforcement of these rules is often lax.Rules on whether schoolchildren must wear masks in class y from state to state.Free rapid tests for all were scrapped nearly a month ago in an effort to incentivise more people to get vaccinated.There are now widespread calls for them to be reintroduced. And officials now advocate booster vaccinations for everyone who got their initial shots six months ago or more.Germany currently has a caretaker national government following the election in September..removeThe parties expected to form the next government plan to bring legislation to parliament this week that would allow an ldquoepidemic situation of national scope, in place since March , to expire at the end of the month, while providing a new legal framework for coronavirus measures..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: German Covid infection rate reaches new high as vaccinations slow

title: rich-mix-needed-house-lords-minister-says-amid-cash-honours-claims
story: A Cabinet minister has defended the peerages system in the UK as she said those in the House of Lords had ldquousually done enormously good work.A Sunday Times report showed  of the last  Conservative Party treasurers have been offered a seat in the Lords, having each donated more than pound million to the party.But International Trade Secretary Anne-Marie Trevelyan said it was key to have a ldquorich mix in the upper chamber.vw,vw,px, px"International Trade Secretary Anne-Marie Trevelyan The Tories have denied any link between the donations and the nominations to sit in the Lords, in the latest twist in ongoing allegations of sleaze.On Monday, Ms Trevelyan said ldquomany business people, who have donated to their parties ndash Lord Sugar is one for the Labour Party, we have some on our side ndash do so because they believe in political activity.She told Sky News: ldquoWe have an incredible system in the UK where we donrsquot ask the state to fund our political parties andwe didnrsquot have the private donations that come through from donors large and small ndash in my constituency, people donate pound a year and donors who can provide more, do more ndashwe didnrsquot do that the taxpayer would be funding political activity.ldquoI think our UK system is uniquely well-placed to ensure that we get this broad stretch hellip the unions fund a great deal of the Labour Partyrsquos activity, again thatrsquos from many, many small voices, and then some large ones too.ldquoItrsquos a mix which brings a real depth of voices to our political parties across the piste.Ms Trevelyan insisted there was a formal process in place, but was challenged on ITVrsquos Good Morning Britain over the Prime Ministerrsquos ability to overrule the Lords appointments commission, as he did with Lord Cruddas.But she told GMB: ldquoSo the Prime Minister always has the final say, the Prime Minister of the day always has the final say, as have other prime ministers in the past..removeMs Trevelyan told Sky News: ldquoI donrsquot think that someone who happens to have been an extremely good businessman and has made a great deal of money through business activity ndash usually also an enormous amount of philanthropy as well, those are the sorts of people who are across our country, amazing people of all political colours ndash that they should be barred from going to the House of Lords because they have made a lot of money, employed many, many thousands of people, run incredible businesses at their own risk, that that somehow is a bar. Thatrsquos not the case.ldquoThose who choose to put themselves forward in political environments, as well as their business and philanthropic ones, will go through the process just like anyone , and we want a rich mix in the House of Lords of voices with experience of all the sectors of our country..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Rich mix needed in House of Lords, minister says, amid cash for honours claims

title: limmys-show-watch-three-series-limmys-show
story: Limmys Show, the sketch series by Scottish comedian Limmy is available to watch on iPlayer from today.Throughout the show, which has a cult following, Limmy plays himself and a iety of other characters in observational comedy sketches.The first series was broadcast in , with the second and third coming in  and  respectively, airing on BBC Scotland.A Christmas special in  marked the final episode, with Limmy saying he didnt want to do any more episodes in the aftermath.Now all three series are available to watch - heres how you can tune in....Where to watch all three series ofLimmys ShowYou can watch all three series of Limmys Show on BBC iPlayer.The original musicaccompanies the show, rather that the musicwhich was substituted when the show appeared on Netflix.There are  episodes across the three series, plus the Christmas special which is also available on iPlayer.Revealing the news, Limmy tweeted: "I am happy to announce that all three series of Limmys Show are now on iPlayer! Including the pilot! And with the original music, not that stuff I had to swap to for Netflix!"I am happy to announce that all three series of Limmys Show are now on iPlayer!Including the pilot!And with the original music, not that stuff I had to swap to for Netflix!https:t.co RKfyFSyomdash twitch.tv LimmyNovember , The Scottish comedian has a huge following on Twitter where he often posts videos of sketches using the handle @DaftLimmy.His extensive fan base will likely be pleased at the news of the release, with series one and two previously only available on DVD, while series three did not come out on disc.It was available for a short period on Netflix, before being removed in .

title: northern-lights-aurora-borealis-can-see-northern-lights-tonight
story: The northern lights were spotted across the UK last night, from Scotlandall the way down to Devon.It is known officially as an aurora borealis, whichis the latin translation of northern lights.These lights occur when there is activity on the earths sun.Atoms and mollecules from the earths atmosphere collide with particles from the sun and create colours in the sky.The earths magnetic field is what causes the wavy lines and patterns of the northern lights.They are a fairly rare occurence, but we in Scotland might get another chance to see them tonight.Heres what we know...Can I see the northern lights in Scotland tonight According to AuroraWatch UK, parts of Scotland could see the northern lights again tonight.Yesterday, areas across the UK reported sightings of the aurora borealis.As of pm on Thursday, AuroraWatch UK reported "minor geomagnetic activity" on its Facebook page, meaning there is a possibility of an aurora laterthis activity continues.It advised checking the site again when it was dark for confirmation of whether or not the northern lights could be seen in Scotland tonight.The site is available here.The chance of seeing an aurora is on the left side of the graph, while the time is along the bottom of the graph.A red alert means it is likely an aurora will occur, while an amber alert means a possible aurora.Earlier in the day, the site had reported a red alert meaning that an aurora was likely, however this has decreased as the day has gone on.Meanwhile, Met Office space weather expert Krista Hammond also confirmed there was a chance of spotting the lights again tonight."As was predicted by the Met Office Space Weather Operations Centre, a coronal mass ejection impacted with the Earth yesterday."The resulting strong geomagnetic storm meant the Northern Lights were visible across large areas of the UK overnight last night."Wersquove had reports that the aurora could even be seen in some central areas of the UK, which is possible when a storm of this magnitude impacts the Earth..remove"This means there is the potential for further sightings of the Northern Lights overnight, although there will be spells of patchy cloud over Scotland which could limit visibility in places."What time am I most likely to see an aurora The northern lights are usually most visible between pm and am, however they could be spotted any time during the hours of darkness.

title: thought for the week october 15 2021
story: One morning recently, I heard the following two news items on the radio:First was a report about the petrochemical plant at Grangemouth which emits tons of CO into the atmosphere. There are plans to convert it to a hydrogen plant which would capture the CO, send it along a pipeline to Aberdeenshire ready for it to be stored deep under the sea.That was immediately followed by a report on the shortage of CO caused by the increase in energy costs and the closing down of two fertilizer factories which send CO on to other industries, in particular food.How ironic – one industry wants to bury the stuff that others desperately need!I decided to find out more and discovered that CO in ying grades of purity is used in a wide iety of industries.On further research, I also discovered that CO is already being turned from a pollutant into a resource.Companies around the world, including the UK, are reusing CO to make building blocks, cement, foam housing insulation and fuel.I found two examples of companies feeding CO to algae, one to make carbon fibre and the other to revive oyster reefs.#Now it is required that those who have been given a trust must prove faithful.# We are all responsible for the care of our planet, whether as members of faith groups or members of a global society.Refining CO might cost a fortune but not doing so could cost the earth.

title: letters october 22 2021
story: It was great to speak to my constituents in Carradale on my latest visit to the village last Saturday.Many residents mentioned the need to cut the grass verges, especially at junctions, for safety reasons. I have contacted Argyll and Bute Council#s roads management about this on numerous occasions and will continue to do so.I have also been in contact with East Kintyre Community Council about the state of signs at passing places in the area. There are roughly  passing places, some with no signs, some with old and badly deteriorated posts and some with new signs.With the increase in use of many East Kintyre roads, it makes sense to have clearly marked passing places.With more and more people working from home, fit-for-purpose broadband speeds and mobile phone coverage is not just a luxury, but an essential tool for day-to-day le. I have been lobbying BT Openreach and local and national governments for more digital investment in our rural ward.I will continue to work day-in and day-out for our area, making sure voices in Kintyre and the islands are heard.As a clinical nurse specialist on Breast Cancer Now#s helpline, I#m acutely aware of the shattering impact of the Covid- pandemic on the emotional wellbeing of people with breast cancer.News of a diagnosis can be a lonely experience and the pandemic has, at times, exacerbated this, denying people the chance to be with loved ones.We#ve seen a sharp rise in calls to our helpline and emails to our Ask Our Nurses service from people struggling emotionally. Many say the loneliness they#ve felt living with breast cancer during the pandemic has been the hardest emotional impact to cope with and that it has negatively impacted their mental health.As many of us look ahead to a #new normal# beyond the pandemic, we must acknowledge the loneliness legacy facing people who#ve lived with breast cancer through the pandemic and commit to addressing it.This Breast Cancer Awareness Month, we want to remind everyone affected by breast cancer that we#re always with you, in every way we can.Thanks to support from players of People#s Postcode Lottery, our online support services are one click away for anyone after a breast cancer diagnosis.Whether you#re a younger woman, adjusting to le after treatment, or living with incurable secondary breast cancer, our tailored support provides a confidential, safe space to connect with others and access specialist information.Find out more about Younger Women Together, Moving Forward, Someone Like Me, and Living With Secondary Breast Cancer at breastcancernow.org online-services

title: leader october 22 2021
story: It is dficult to understand the Scottish Conservative and Unionist Party#s decision not to allow Donald Kelly to represent the party at the  local election – especially when it will not provide a reason.Councillor Kelly said he met #a wall of silence# when asking for a proper explanation or justication, and the Courier has had a similar experience, with numerous attempts to gain answers proving unsuccessful.We asked why the decision was made and why Councillor Kelly was not made aware or given notice of itit was in relation to his Argyll First membership and why support from former Scottish Conservative leaders Annabel Goldie and Ruth Davidson appeared not to be taken into consideration.If we do receive answers to our questions, we will share them with our readers but until then we can only speculate.Surely Councillor Kelly and the people of South Kintyre deserve to know.Congratulations to Fraser Cursiter and Katie Webster who got engaged this week after Fraser proposed on the beach in Carradale.We wish the couple, who are soon moving to Australia, the best of luck for the future we hope theyto visit the place that has earned a special place in their hearts.

title: thought for the week october 22 2021
story: As we crossed the bridge, we were excited to see the island’s beauty.At first though, we had to take our friend’s word for it, as rain, low cloud and failing light obscured most of it from view. The next day the rain stopped, the clouds lted and the sun broke through.We saw for ourselves that what our friend had said was true. Skye’s scenery is stunning.In John, chapter , verses -, the apostles told Thomas that while he had been away, Jesus had physically appeared to them. Thomas refused to accept as true what they told him, insisting that unless he saw him with his own eyes and touched him with his own hands, he would not believe Jesus was alive.For him, seeing was believing.Later, Jesus once again appeared to the apostles and, this time, Thomas was present. Now Thomas believed. Jesus rebuked him for his unbelief and said: ‘Blessed are those who have not seen yet believe.’We believe lots of things, not because we can see them for ourselves but by accepting the word of those who have.Christians believe in Jesus, not because we have seen him with our own eyes, but because of the reliable word of the apostles who physically saw the risen Jesus with their own eyes.I encourage you to read the Gospels, the accurately written-down eyewitness testimony of the apostles to Jesus so that you might see who he is and as you trust in him alone,

title: cinema prepares of weekend of halloween horrors
story: As part of the national BFI Japan  season, the cinema organised a spooky line-up featuring frightening monster turtles, giant pigs, family anime, whisky tasting, claymation, filmmaking and what is probably the scariest movie of all time.The BFI Japan  entertainment kicked off last Friday, with a screening of Lost in Translation, which was followed by a Japanese whisky-tasting session led by Mark and Kate Watt of Watt Whisky.Tomorrowmorning, children aged between eight and  can get a taste of monster model-making courtesy of Jim Parkyn, lead modelmaker at Aardman Animations, the studio behind Wallace and Gromit and Shaun the Sheep.Jim will help the youngsters create their own monsters, inspired by the likes of Godzilla, the original kaiju – Japanese monster – on film.The children could see their own creations tearing up the Wee Toon as the models will then be used to create a special monster movie which will be screened the following day, on Hallowe#en itself, alongside Gamera: The Giant Monster.Parents are welcome to sit in on the workshop which will last  minutes and will include a chance to ask questions and hear about the master model-maker#s work.The £ workshop ticket includes entry to Gamera: The Giant Monster but spaces are limited and those interested are advised to book as soon as possible.On Saturday afternoon, there will be family anime with Studio Ghibli#s multi-award-winning Spirited Away, considered to be one of the greatest animated films.In the evening, for horror lovers who are brave enough to be scared out of their skins, there#s a rare opportunity to catch the original Ring – Ringu – on the big screen.Ellen Mainwood, Campbeltown Picture House Manager, said: #What more could anyone want of Hallowe#en – giant fire-breathing prehistoric turtle monsters, parents turned into pigs, claymation fun and terrying horror #We#re delighted to be part of the BFI Japan  season, a nationwide celebration of the best of Japanese film.#Tickets for all events, listed below, are on sale now at www.campbeltownpicturehouse

title: from our files october 29 2021
story: Campbeltown#s vital Ring and Ride bus service is safe – for now.It was granted a last-minute reprieve from council budget cuts on Wednesday, two days before it was due to be scrapped.Argyll and Bute Council agreed to continue the Ring and Ride service whilst it takes time to look for an alternative.Councillor Rory Colville, community spokesman for Argyll and Bute Council, said: #We are responding to the concerns of the people who need this service most.#It will continue in its current form for as long as it takes to make an informed decision about changes and we will make people aware of what will be provided in the future.#No timescale was given as to whether this would be before next May#s elections.In last year#s budget, the service was earmarked for the axe at the time, but the council gave assurances alternative arrangements would be put in place.Councillor John Semple said: #I am glad to see that finally some common sense seems to be filtering through – only three weeks ago the administration voted to continue with this cut.#I will continue to look after the interests of the most vulnerable people in this community as the administration#s plans materialise.#Argyll First councillor Donald Kelly was a prime mover in establishing and expanding the service and is totally against the withdrawal.He told the Courier that this is only a stay of execution for this service and assurances are needed that the service will be retained in the long-term.TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGOThe MP for Argyll and Bute has pressed for additional facts about the ferry service between Campbeltown and Ballycastle.During last Friday#s Scottish Questions in the House of Commons, Mrs Ray Michie pressed the Secretary of State for Scotland, Mr Michael Forsyth, for more information.She said: #I welcome the announcement, at long last, of the ferry service, although I am disappointed Caledonian MacBrayne was not allowed to run it.#She went on to ask: #For how long does Sea Containers have the contract  Is the Secretary of State expecting the service eventually to run all year, so that we can build up not only a good tourist service, but a good import and export trade #Mr Forsyth responded: #It was important for the new route to be established. It was possible to achieve that with a private sector operator taking the risk, which means that CalMac#s available public capital and running costs can be deployed on maintaining other services and introducing new ones.#It must be the right approach to use the state#s nationalised service and the scarce resources available to it as wisely as possible.#That was what lay behind our thinking.#He went on to say that he would write to Mrs Michie regarding the contract.Mrs Michie commented: #It is important we get the full facts about this service so that we can judge whether this really is value for money as the government claims.#FIFTY YEARS AGOEmergency sea rescue services in the Firth of Clyde could have been victims of another hoax on Friday.For the Campbeltown leboat, three naval vessels and a Dakota aircraft spent nearly six hours searching Kilbrannan Sound and its approaches for a boat reported to have been sinking off Campbeltown.The drama began at lunchtime when the Campbeltown leboat mechanic, Mr Alistair Gilchrist, intercepted a wireless message which read: #Mayday Boy Danny sinking  degrees off Campbeltown.#Kildonan Coastguard Station, Troon Leboat Station and Portpatrick Radio also picked up the call the boat#s name, however, was not mentioned in the message received by the other three stations.Then a full-scale search operation swung into operation. Along with the leboat, the warship HMS Eastbourne, Fishery Protection vessel Vigilant and the US Navy ship Victoria began combing the area between the south of Arran and Kintyre.They were joined later in the search by a Dakota aircraft from Prestwick.An RAF patrol vessel stood by at Campbeltown.Campbeltown leboat reported the discovery of a large piece of timber. It was, however, too heavy to lt aboard and it was not thought to be part of possible wreckage.Then, after six hours, the search was called off. The plane and boats had covered an extensive area of sea.Coastguards using mobile equipment searched along the shores of Arran and Kintyre.Nothing was seen.Police in Campbeltown began investigations into the matter shortly after the leboat put to sea their enquiries are continuing.ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGOAuchencorvie United, one of the teams that came into being in the rural area as a result of the formation of sports clubs among agricultural workers, made their first appearance in local competitive football last Saturday afternoon.Drumlemble supplied the opposition and had a comparatively easy victory by four goals to nil.Auchencorvie had several players of some promise but, as a whole, the team was sadly wanting in science and judgement and the lesson of their first experience should impress on them the fact that mere lusty vigour is not sufficient to win on the football field.In the first half, Drumlemble did not press their undoubted superiority unduly, being content with a one-goal lead at the interval. James Munro was the scorer.In the second half they added three more to the total, D Thomson having two and A Kerr one.At the opening concert of the winter session of the Scottish Clans# Association of London Mr Charles Kelly, a well-known Campbeltown vocalist, sang with much success.His pieces were The March of the Cameron Men, The Lea Rigg, I Passed By Your Window and Until.In all these numbers he had a fine reception, especially from Campbeltonians in the audience of whom there seemed to be a goodly number.A correspondent writing with regard to the work of the association says that there are probably a good many Kintyre folk in London who would find it a great pleasure to join the Scottish Clans and take part in society#s many s.The atmosphere is truly Scottish and the gatherings have a homeliness about them which appeals greatly to the newcomer.

title: late late show as pupils cruelly lose out
story: Campbeltown Pupils were left to rue the loss of another late goal last Saturday after an th-minute strike resigned the Kintyre Park side to a narrow defeat away to St Peter#s.Playing at Renfrew FC#s impressive New Western Park, the McFadyens-sponsored Pupils started the match brightly, despite another y injury list which saw several established first-team players ruled out and others unavailable due to work commitments.The Pupils took the lead before the -minute mark when John McCallum, playing at right wing in a --- formation, reacted quickest to Craig Lamont#s long throw-in, which bounced up on the dry synthetic surface, to guide a deft looping header beyond the reach of the St Peter#s keeper.The Kintyre side had efforts from left winger Scott Souden and lone striker Sean Grady go wide of the target – the latter#s promising effort deflected wide of goal – while McCallum was released by Grady and rounded the hosts# keeper only for his cutback to be cleared for a corner, away from the feet of the waiting Souden.At the other end, the Pupils had a new-look combination in defence, with full backs Craig Lamont and Michael McKinlay, and Ross Souden in central defence partnered by -year-old debutant Antonio Akoulli, studying in Scotland and hailing from Thessaloniki, Greece.The four had to be alert to the efforts of St Peter#s wingers Menzies and Lewis on either flank, and did so very well for the opening  minutes until a lapse in concentration saw Scott Lewis – signed from fellow WoSFL side Benburb FC for a transfer fee – ghost along the edge of the box and slot home a fine finish across keeper Alasdair Ferguson with his weaker left foot, into the young keeper’s bottom left-hand corner to make it -.Impressively, the Pupils rebounded from this setback and scored with  minutes played when Liam Renton, playing as an attacking midfielder, latched onto a ball from Scott Souden just inside the hosts# box, and turned his marker sharply before guiding a left-footed shot beyond the keeper#s grasp.All the while, the Pupils# deep-lying midfield pairing – a real contrast of experience levels between skipper Keith Mitchell, and Conner Brown beside him making his club debut – continued to break up play and keep the Feathers Inn-sponsored side moving forward.Despite this, there was a further scare in the visitors# penalty area when St Peter#s hit the bar from a powerful volleyed shot on the stroke of half time, but the Pupils# lead remained intact.Into the second half, though, the Pupils were pegged back in the opening few minutes of proceedings, a clever turn and precise shot beyond the grasp of Ferguson providing a fine equaliser.Admirably from a Pupils point of view, there was no onslaught from the ision#s third-placed team, also boasting a loan signing from Greenock FC, another semi-professional side, in their midfield ranks, and smatterings of semi-pro experience across their starting .However, what followed instead was a gradual build-up of pressure which the Pupils had to work increasingly hard to contain, the home side#s willing forwards continuing to probe for openings in the visitors# defence.The hard-working pair of Matthew Lang and Calum Houston were introduced in attack for the Pupils with  minutes remaining, with fresh legs required as the embattled visitors# energy levels began to wane.But even the dismissal of Lewis for the hosts, hitting out at Renton in reaction to a robust tackle from the latter, which earned the Pupils man a booking, couldn#t deny the Paisley side a late, late winner, a long ball going undefended in the Pupils ranks, and slotted home in the box by a St Peter#s midfielder to give them all three points, and in turn deny the Pupils a probably deserved draw.The Pupils# management team conveyed thanks to the travelling players for their efforts, even in defeat, and will surely take consolation from giving experience to young talent in the side, with four club debuts made in the space of week – after -year-old Andrew Renton#s appearance against Rossvale on cup duty – and within that clutch, a potentially very useful defensive addition.Tomorrow , the Pupils are at home to Glenvale FC, from Paisley, again on league duty, with kick off at pm.For more information, visit @PupilsAFC on Twitter or Campbeltown Football on Facebook.

title: leader october 29 2021
story: More must be done to prevent the continued spate of thefts which have  blighted Kintyre farms in recent years.To be targeted once must be incredibly frightening but some farmers have been targeted again and again, despite following advice to increase security and lock vehicles away.Maybe now that non-farming vehicles have also been stolen – a van in , a car in March  and another car last week – the wider community may realise the seriousness of the situation.The impact of rural crime takes a huge toll on the mental health of those who live in rural areas like Kintyre, many of whom choose to live here because of the low crime rates.It is therefore heartening that everyone the Courier spoke to in relation to the thefts seems genuinely keen to work collaboratively towards a solution.Parents must make sure their opinions are known about Argyll and Bute Council#s proposal to cluster some Argyll and Bute schools.No matter your opinion –you think an amalgamated Kintyre super-school would create a united front oryou think a dedicated headteacher for each school is better – you must make your voice heard.

title: letters october 29 2021
story: We know this winter is likely to be a dficult one for parents due to the risks caused by Respiratory Syncytial Virusinfections.RSV is a common virus that causes cold-like symptoms but can cause critical illnesses such as bronchiolitis in babies born premature or sick.RSV is usually most prevalent in Scotland between October and March each year.Throughout the Covid- pandemic, restrictions in social contact meant that cases of RSV were reduced. Since people began mixing again, there has steadily been an increase in cases ahead of the usual winter seasonal trend, mainly in children aged under five.Bliss will be working to provide information and support about RSV and respiratory infections directly to families of premature and sick babies at neonatal units across Scotland.We are urging all parents to know the warning signs of respiratory conditions and to contact their health care professional when they need to.In the early stages, RSV symptoms are similar to a common cold .Symptoms usually last between one and three weeks. If the lungs are affected, one or more of the following symptoms will develop or get worse:To find out more, please visit bliss.org.uk RSVA new campaign has been launched urging defibrillator owners to register their devices on a national database to help save more lives from cardiac arrests.Leading charities and health organisations are calling for defibrillators to be registered on The Circuit – the national defibrillator network, which connects defibrillators to NHS ambulance services across the UK.When someone calls  to report a cardiac arrest, call handlers are trained to provide the location of the nearest registered defibrillator within m of the call. Studies show that using a defibrillator within three minutes of collapse, along with starting CPR, can greatly increase chances of survival.This swt action can make a real dference, and The Circuit is a vital tool in helping increase bystander action to help someone in cardiac arrest.We would urge everyone to register the defibrillators that they are responsible for, so that they can be easily located and accessed when needed.It#s free to register your defibrillator onto The Circuit, and you only have to do it once. You can also register multiple defibrillatorsyou areto more than one.Visit www.thecircuit.uk for more information.

title: team nets new bags
story: The purchase of the holdalls was possible thanks to a donation to the under s team from Wylie Hume.#Everyone involved at the s would like to say a massive thanks to Wylie for his kind donation,# said David Paterson, team manager.#As many will know, Wylie himself was heavily involved in the local children#s football association in the s and s and wished to show support to our efforts.#Along with a small payment from parents, rucksacks were also purchased with Campbeltown and District Juvenile Football Association#s help – as is the case for all age groups in the association.#Thanks from all involved at the s.#

title: thought for the week october 29 2021
story: Although the autumn marks the end of summer, for many looking ahead, it#s filled with excitement and anticipation as Christmas approaches. The countdown begins!There are many good things in le we look forward to: a sunny day, a bike ride, the weekend, holidays, retirement or a new job.At dferent times we look forward to dferent things, but behind them all is a common search.The French scientist and mathematician Blaise Pascal said: #All people seek happiness. This is without exception##He said that whatever our idea of how to reach it, our desire never takes the smallest step except towards the goal of happiness it is the desire behind every ambition.But from time to time we recognise our search is misleading, happiness doesn#t last, the clouds come, the ride ends, Monday morning always follows#Three time Wimbledon champion Boris Becker said: #I had won Wimbledon twice before, once as the youngest player. I was rich I had all the material possessions I needed.#It#s the old song of movie stars# they have everything, and yet they are so unhappy. I had no inner peace, I was a puppet on a string.#Where, then, is lasting happiness to be found The bible teaches us that every wonderful thing we enjoy is both a gt and sign pointing us to the giver, our creator God who loves us.If we hope to find ultimate happiness in His gts, we expect too much#We were designed through those gts to enjoy the God who gave them and to find true joy in Him.#I have come [said Jesus] that you may have le and have it to the full.#

title: west coast motors 100 years of bringing people together part iii
story: A century after Campbeltown-based coach operator West Coast Motors was founded, bus enthusiast Lawrence Macduff, who splits his time between Kilmarnock and Dunoon, has penned a commemorate article delving into the company#s history from  to the present day.The piece, and several photographs also supplied by Lawrence, is being published in the Courier. Photographs from the early days up to  are from the collections of the late Robert Grieves and from John Sinclair, two indefatigable photographers whose material is of national Scottish importance. This week#s article is the conclusion.West Coast#s business portfolio now extends well beyond Kintyre.In , it bought the Glasgow Citybus concern which operates on the north side of the Clyde.Two years on, it also picked up a city tour business which is now operated under the City Sightseeing franchise in Glasgow.It also operates the inter-rail station shuttle in the city.An interesting ersication in  was what became a fast passenger ferry link from Campbeltown to Ballycastle while a few years further on, Fairline Coaches, based near the company#s Glasgow Citybus depot in Whiteinch, Glasgow, was absorbed into West Coast.The company also won the contract to operate Citylink#s new Glasgow-Edinburgh Airport service and additionally, partnered Fort William-based Shiel Buses on Citylink#s Glasgow-Fort William and Skye services.Perhaps the biggest and most signicant recent extension of West Coast#s business came with the creation of Borders Buses. The company acquired services radiating into the region from Edinburgh as well local route networks taking it as far south as Berwick on Tweed.As a result, the West Coast identity is to be found all over the Borders.Combined vehicle strength is now around , a far cry from fewer than  in the s.I#d like to conclude this abbreviated survey with two final observations. Firstly, I wish to acknowledge and applaud the drive and foresight of the Craig family in building the business from its original heartland in the southernmost area of Argyll.Public transport is full of challenges whether air, sea, rail or road and, as in every field of business le, there are never any guarantees of success.Once any business reaches a successful position, it often requires even more effort to maintain it there, let alone continue to grow it in size and influence.The presence of Covid since  has, of course, created major dficulties for every business virtually across the board.Finally, a word of praise for the staff and especially for those who are engaged on the vital long-distance links, particularly the Campbeltown, Oban and Skye services.These routes are not only amongst the most weather prone in Scotland, they operate almost exclusively over ordinary trunk roads, iniably convoluted in nature and of borderline width for the safe transit of long vehicles.A driver myself, though never on any of these routes, I#m familiar with all these roads and have some perception of the extreme challenges drivers frequently face.To them, and to all the company#s staff and management, I, and I#m sure many readers who are users of the services West Coast Motors provide across Argyll and in other parts of Scotland, offer grateful thanks.

title: muddy good rugby festival at taynuilt
story: More than  players from Campbeltown, Lochgilphead, Oban, Fort William, Mull and Taynuilt took part with some fantastic rugby on display across all the age groups from the Micro P-Ps to the P s.Conditions were damp under foot given the amount of rain that has been falling lately. The rain on the day did not dampen the enthusiasm of everyone taking revelling in rolling about in the mud.Congratulations to Kintyre who won both the P  and the P  competitions. They had a real desire to compete and were deserved winners.It was also great to see Mull being represented again after missing the last few festivals and they acquitted themselves well in their first games under their new coaches.A big game of girls touch rugby topped off a great day with all the girls taking part to celebrate Women and Girls in Sport week. This was one of the highlights of the day with the youngest player in P all the way through to the P’sA big thank you to everyone at Etive Vikings for their hospitality. The last festival of the season will take place at Lochaber Rugby Club, Fort William on Sunday November .All pics in D photosMain photograph : Isle of Mull players take a well earned rest.

title: muddy good rugby festival at taynuilt 2
story: Youngsters from the Kintyre-Campbeltown team joined players from Lochgilphead, Oban, Fort William, Mull and Taynuilt, with some fantastic rugby on display across all the age groups from the micro P-Ps to the P-s.Conditions were damp underfoot, given the amount of rain that has been falling lately.But the rain on the day did not dampen the enthusiasm of everyone revelling in rolling about in the mud.#Congratulations to Kintyre who won both the P  and the P  competitions,# said a spokesperson. #They had a real desire to compete and were deserved winners.#It was also great to see Mull being represented again after missing the last few festivals and they acquitted themselves well in their first games under their new coaches.#A big game of girls# touch rugby topped off a great day with all the girls taking part to celebrate Women and Girls in Sport week.This was one of the highlights of the day with the youngest player in P, all the way through to the Ps.The last festival of the season will take place at Lochaber Rugby Club, Fort William on Sunday November .

title: pupils u15s defeated by top of the league team
story: Campbeltown Pupils shosted top-of-the-league Clyde Community s last Sunday, in their first home game in ision one.The Kintyre side has been working hard on the fundamentals of football and managing to hit the mark.Both teams started the game very strong and it was a great first-half from the local side, with the scoreline level at - when the half-time whistle blew.The travelling Clyde side found their feet very quickly in the second half and held a strong back four which the Campbeltown side could not penetrate.With the visitors# scoring three further goals, the final score was Campbeltown Pupils , Clyde Community .

title: spooky sporting activities
story: Participants of both sports dressed up as they took part in activities last Sunday, on October , All Hallows# Eve itself.Paddleboarders dressed up as witches, a cowgirl, Ghostface and sported spooky head boppers as they enjoyed a ride on Campbeltown Loch.And young golfers donned their glow-in-the-dark gear as they took part in an evening competition at Machrihanish Golf Club before changing into their own frightening costumes for a party in the clubhouse afterwards.

title: amazons first uk windfarm comes online in kintyre
story: The company has announced it will purchase  per cent of the power output from ScottishPower Renewables# Beinn an Tuirc  windfarm.The largest ScottishPower windfarm to be built without a government support scheme, its construction was enabled by Amazon#s Power Purchase Agreement The MW, -turbine windfarm is now generating enough electricity to power the equivalent of almost , homes, bringing more green energy on to the UK grid.The energy generated will power Amazon and Amazon Web Servicesdata centres, corporate offices and fulfilment centres across the UK.PPAs allow developers to invest in and build new green infrastructure projects with a clear route to market and without relying on public funding for renewable energy while corporate customers benefit from a trusted source of clean energy, certainty, and a reduction in their own carbon footprint.Speaking last week, Lindsay McQuade, chief executive officer of ScottishPower Renewables, said: #It#s really exciting to mark the completion of Beinn an Tuirc  and the start of our PPA with Amazon during UK Wind Week and with just a few days to go until the COP UN Climate Change Conference gets underway.#If we#re going to reach net zero over the next  years, we need to quadruple the amount of renewable energy produced in the UK so we can move away from petrol and diesel cars electry public transport get rid of gas boilers and move to electric heating for our homes and lower emissions from heavy industry and the goods and services we rely on every day.#We#re proud to have delivered Amazon#s first renewable project in the UK, supporting The Climate Pledge and the company#s commitment to be net-zero carbon across its business by .#This will support a greener and more sustainable economy and help us all enjoy a cleaner and better future, quicker.#John Boumphrey, Amazon#s UK country manager, added: #Amazon is on a path to powering our operations with  per cent renewable energy by , five years ahead of schedule.#We are excited that our first Scottish windfarm is now contributing to that goal, and we have three more large-scale renewable projects in development across the UK.#Investing in clean energy and working across all of our operations to become more efficient is just one of the many actions we are taking to reach our commitment as part of The Climate Pledge to be net-zero carbon by .#South Kintyre#s three councillors welcomed the news and the potential benefits it could bring to Kintyre.Councillor John Armour said: #I am delighted that Kintyre has been chosen and recognised in taking this forward.#It highlights the fact that with the right will from all concerned Kintyre can be a hub for future wind turbine production and for work connected with the ongoing maintenance of windfarms.#We have a purpose-built factory and top-class workforce so we need to see all parties working together to bring this all together.#Argyll First Councillor Donald Kelly added: #It is encouraging that Amazon is trying to reduce its carbon footprint through investing in Beinn an Tuirc .#This certainly raises the profile of Kintyre#s capability to be part of the ongoing drive to deliver onshore renewable energy projects.#Councillor Rory Colville said: #Whilst this partnership approach has undoubtedly put Kintyre on the map, what could be truly transformational isAmazon, using energy direct from Beinn an Tuirc , based its AWS data centre here in Kintyre.#Recently, MACC Business Park was promoted in the national press as a site for a new green datacentre all it needs is for some or all of the new proposed transatlantic cable to be channelled in to the base. It could be the start of a whole new industry.#In other green energy news, Chancellor Rishi Sunak has awarded a funding package to a Kintyre-based hydrogen production and distribution project under the UK Government#s Community Renewal Fund.As outlined in the Chancellor#s Budget, £, has been awarded to the MACC Hydrogen Futures viability study, through which Machrihanish Airbase Community Company plans to complete a detailed feasibility and design project with a view to establishing a green hydrogen production and distribution facility.£, was also awarded to help fund feasibility studies, business plans, investment cases and planning applications as a prelude to a £ million transformation project to regenerate Tarbert.Highlands and Islands MSP Donald Cameron said: #These investment packages from Rishi Sunak are welcome news for Argyll and Bute, and in particular Kintyre.#The chancellor#s financial support from the Community Renewal Fund means that people living in Kintyre will see the benefits of these extremely worthwhile projects that look to regenerate or innovate within their area.#

title: council pledges to keep working with community projects post pandemic
story: An update by the Accounts Commission and Audit Scotland highlighted the authority#s work in the community since the Covid- outbreak and has now called for the momentum to be maintained by councils across Scotland, alongside a determination not toto pre-pandemic ways of working.In response to the call, Argyll and Bute Council highlighted many examples of its work with communities since March .A spokesperson for the council said: #We worked with our partners throughout the pandemic to deliver our communities with a range of support services.#There was huge pressure placed on local businesses and restrictions on how to trade during lockdown and one of the many things we did to help was establish a town centre recovery group during the first weeks of the pandemic.#This included representatives across council services, the police and the private sector, and allowed quick actions to be taken to enable businesses to ersy and adapt to meet customer needs.#For example, easing the need for planning consents and enabling more use of outdoor space including on council land.#These meetings led to further initiatives including a shop local campaign, shopfront grants, permanent improvements to outdoor spaces and digital apps s to help local business prosper and provide information to their customers.#The spokesperson added: #Our joint approach to protecting the most vulnerable people in our society also led to our Community Food Project beating off industry giants to win a national award.#We have continued to work at pace on the development and delivery of the Covid- Micro Grant Fund for village halls and community organisations.#This fund was set up to help communities to recover from the impacts of Covid- and find safe ways to bring people together.#Covid- has had a huge impact on our society and we continue to meet with community response groups on a monthly basis to identy their needs and escalate concerns to partners and other services as required.#Geraldine Wooley from the Accounts Commission said: #Covid- made some public bodies quickly deliver services dferently. In many places, voluntary sector organisations were able to work at pace and with a greater freedom to support their communities.#Community organisations across Scotland have a depth of understanding about local needs, that we should continue to tap into.#They were able to identy those who were most vulnerable, bringing insight into very local issues. Their ability to quickly maximise local knowledge and connections was crucial in the local response.#We urge councils to build on this and notto business as usual. Truly empowered communities are vital in helping reduce the disadvantage and inequalities that have become more severe because of Covid-.#

title: district news november 5 2021
story: In the future, a trip to the city for Kintyre residents could mean taking the long and winding road to Oban instead of Glasgow.Argyll and Bute residents are being urged to get behind the town#s bid to be one of the UK#s newest cities.Cities come in all shapes and sizes and Oban could become one of them in , fighting off stf competition from other towns in the national competition marking the Queen#s platinum jubilee.As part of a campaign headed #Oban – Scotland in one place#, our sister newspaper The Oban Times has joined forces with Argyll and Bute Council to champion the town as a worthy contender for city status.Now council leader Robin Currie is inviting people to get involved and share what they like best about Oban.People#s comments and photographs about what makes Oban a special place to live, work and visit could make all the dference to the town#s bid.Backing the bid is one step of making sure that the town and Argyll has as much chance of a successful future as other parts of Scotland, says Councillor Currie.Council officers are hard at work getting the big bid ready to meet the deadline on December , but need people#s help.Visit www.argyll-bute.gov.uk obancity to share your support and to find out more about the bid and what it could mean for the town.
